natural problem:
Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$
natural solution: \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to

\[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}

5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "A powr 3 + p * (A powr 2) + q * A + r * mat 1 = 0"
shows  "(p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "A powr 3 + p * (A powr 2) + q * A + r * mat 1 = 0"
shows  "(p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix $A = [[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]]$, find the values of $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that $A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0$. The answer is $(p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. ((i = 1 \<and> j = 2) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 3) \<or> (i = 3 \<and> j = 1)) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j. ((i = 1 \<and> j = 3) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 1) \<or> (i = 3 \<and> j = 2)) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> i j. (i = j) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> i j. (i = j) \<longrightarrow> I $ i $ j = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> i j. (i \<noteq> j) \<longrightarrow> I $ i $ j = 0"
and h5 : "(A^3 + 0 *: A^2 - 6 *: A - 4 *: I = 0)"
shows  "True"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. ((i = 1 \<and> j = 2) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 3) \<or> (i = 3 \<and> j = 1)) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j. ((i = 1 \<and> j = 3) \<or> (i = 2 \<and> j = 1) \<or> (i = 3 \<and> j = 2)) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> i j. (i = j) \<longrightarrow> A $ i $ j = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> i j. (i = j) \<longrightarrow> I $ i $ j = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> i j. (i \<noteq> j) \<longrightarrow> I $ i $ j = 0"
and h5 : "(A^3 + 0 *: A^2 - 6 *: A - 4 *: I = 0)"
shows  "True"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider two 3x3 matrices A and I. Matrix A is defined as follows: the entries of A at positions (1,2), (2,3), and (3,1) are 1, the entries at positions (1,3), (2,1), and (3,2) are 2, and the diagonal entries (i.e., positions (1,1), (2,2), and (3,3)) are 0. Matrix I is the identity matrix, with ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere. If the cubic matrix equation A^3 + 0*A^2 - 6*A - 4*I = 0 holds, then the statement is true.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and O :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "O = mat 0"
and h3 : "A^3 + p * A^2 + q * A + r * I = O"
shows  "p = 0 \<and> q = -6 \<and> r = -4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and O :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "O = mat 0"
and h3 : "A^3 + p * A^2 + q * A + r * I = O"
shows  "p = 0 \<and> q = -6 \<and> r = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A = [[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]], find the coefficients p, q, and r such that the cubic matrix equation A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0 is satisfied, where I is the 3x3 identity matrix and 0 is a 3x3 matrix of zeros. The final answer is p = 0, q = -6, and r = -4.

a_3.formal problem:
definition A :: "int^3^3" where
"A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"

definition I :: "int^3^3" where
"I = matrix([[1,0,0], [0,1,0], [0,0,1]])"

definition Zero :: "int^3^3" where
"Zero = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,0], [0,0,0]])"

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<exists>p q r. ((A^^3) + p *^ (A^^2) + q *^ A + r *^ I = Zero)"
shows  "h0 = (0, -6, -4)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

definition A :: "int^3^3" where
"A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"

definition I :: "int^3^3" where
"I = matrix([[1,0,0], [0,1,0], [0,0,1]])"

definition Zero :: "int^3^3" where
"Zero = matrix([[0,0,0], [0,0,0], [0,0,0]])"

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<exists>p q r. ((A^^3) + p *^ (A^^2) + q *^ A + r *^ I = Zero)"
shows  "h0 = (0, -6, -4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find constants p, q, and r such that the cubic polynomial $A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0$, where A is the matrix [[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]], I is the identity matrix, and 0 is the zero matrix. The final answer is (p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4).

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "\<exists>p q r. ((A^3) + p * (A^2) + q * A + r * mat 1 = 0)"
shows  "(p,q,r) = (0, -6, -4)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "\<exists>p q r. ((A^3) + p * (A^2) + q * A + r * mat 1 = 0)"
shows  "(p,q,r) = (0, -6, -4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the values of $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that the cubic matrix equation $A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0$ is satisfied, where $A$ is a $3 \times 3$ matrix with rows [0,1,2], [1,0,1], and [2,1,0], and $I$ is the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix. The final answer is $(p,q,r) = (0, -6, -4)$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and O :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "O = mat 0"
and h3 : "matrix_pow A 3 + p * matrix_pow A 2 + q * A + r * I = O"
shows  "p = 0" "q = -6" "r = -4"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and O :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "O = mat 0"
and h3 : "matrix_pow A 3 + p * matrix_pow A 2 + q * A + r * I = O"
shows  "p = 0" "q = -6" "r = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let A be a 3x3 matrix with the elements as [[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]], I be the 3x3 identity matrix, and O be the 3x3 zero matrix. If the cubic equation of A, expressed as $A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = O$, holds true, find the values of the scalars p, q, and r. The final Answer is p = 0, q = -6, r = -4.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
defines A_def: "A == |[|0,1,2|], [|1,0,1|], [|2,1,0|]|"
and pqr_def: "pqr A p q r == (A^3 + p *^ (A^2) + q *^ A + r *^ mat 1 = 0)"
assumes h0 : "pqr A 0 (-6) (-4)"
shows  "p = 0" "q = -6" "r = -4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
defines A_def: "A == |[|0,1,2|], [|1,0,1|], [|2,1,0|]|"
and pqr_def: "pqr A p q r == (A^3 + p *^ (A^2) + q *^ A + r *^ mat 1 = 0)"
assumes h0 : "pqr A 0 (-6) (-4)"
shows  "p = 0" "q = -6" "r = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A with rows [0,1,2], [1,0,1], and [2,1,0], find the values of p, q, and r such that the equation A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0 holds, where I is the 3x3 identity matrix. It is known that pqr A 0 -6 -4. The final answer is p = 0, q = -6, r = -4.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A p q r :: "real^3^3"
and I :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. I $ i $ j = (if i = j then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "A = matrix (\<lambda>(i,j). if j = i+1 then 1 else if j = i-1 then 1 else if j = i+2 then 2 else if j = i-2 then 2 else 0)"
and h2 : "A powr 3 + p * (A powr 2) + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "p = 0" and "q = -6" and "r = -4"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A p q r :: "real^3^3"
and I :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. I $ i $ j = (if i = j then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "A = matrix (\<lambda>(i,j). if j = i+1 then 1 else if j = i-1 then 1 else if j = i+2 then 2 else if j = i-2 then 2 else 0)"
and h2 : "A powr 3 + p * (A powr 2) + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "p = 0" and "q = -6" and "r = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a 3x3 identity matrix $I$ where $I_{ij} = 1$ if $i = j$ and $0$ otherwise, and a 3x3 matrix $A$ where $A_{ij} = 1$ if $j = i+1$ or $j = i-1$, $A_{ij} = 2$ if $j = i+2$ or $j = i-2$, and $0$ otherwise. If it holds that $A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0$, find the values of $p$, $q$, and $r$. The final answers are $p = 0$, $q = -6$, and $r = -4$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = (1,1):map_matrix real_of_integer (1::int^3^3)"
and h2 : "A ^ 3 + p * (A ^ 2) + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "(p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and I :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2],[1,0,1],[2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = (1,1):map_matrix real_of_integer (1::int^3^3)"
and h2 : "A ^ 3 + p * (A ^ 2) + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "(p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A with rows [0,1,2], [1,0,1], and [2,1,0], and the 3x3 identity matrix I, find real numbers p, q, r such that A cubed plus p times A squared plus q times A plus r times I is the zero matrix. The final answer is (p, q, r) = (0, -6, -4).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A I 0 :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "0 = mat 0"
and h3 : "A ^ 3 + p * A ^ 2 + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "p = 0 \<and> q = -6 \<and> r = -4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let
\[\bold{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]There exist constants $p$, $q$, and $r$ such that
\[\bold{A}^3 + p \bold{A}^2 + q \bold{A} + r \bold{I} = \bold{0},\]where $\bold{I}$ and $\bold{0}$ are the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively.  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$ The final Answer is (0,-6,-4)
 ### Proof
 We see that \[\bold{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\]and
 \[\bold{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want $p$, $q$, and $r$ to satisfy
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 6 & 12 \\ 6 & 4 & 6 \\ 12 & 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} + p \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]The left-hand side is equal to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} 5p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 & p + 2q + 12 \\ 2p + q + 6 & 2p + r + 4 & 2p + q + 6 \\ p + 2q + 12 & 2p + q + 6 & 5p + r + 4 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations \begin{align}
 5p + r &= -4, \\ 2p + q &= -6, \\ p + 2q &= -12, \\ 2p + r &= -4. \end{align}Solving this system, we find $(p,q,r) = \boxed{(0,-6,-4)}.$ Note: The polynomial $x^3+px^2+qx+r$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\mathbf A.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A I 0 :: "real^3^3" and p q r :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]])"
and h1 : "I = mat 1"
and h2 : "0 = mat 0"
and h3 : "A ^ 3 + p * A ^ 2 + q * A + r * I = 0"
shows  "p = 0 \<and> q = -6 \<and> r = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A with elements A = [[0,1,2], [1,0,1], [2,1,0]], find the values of p, q, and r such that the cubic matrix equation A^3 + pA^2 + qA + rI = 0 is satisfied, where I is the 3x3 identity matrix. The final answer is p = 0, q = -6, and r = -4.
